statement.text: Abdominal aortic aneurysm affects 4-8% of men over 65 years and 0.5-1.5% of women over 65 years. Smoking is the strongest modifiable risk factor, increasing risk 5-8 fold. AAA accounts for approximately 15,000 deaths annually in the United States.
statement.formal: AAA Prevalence: Men ≥65: 4-8%, Women ≥65: 0.5-1.5% | Major Risk Factors: Smoking (RR 5-8), Male sex (RR 4-6), Age >65, Family history (RR 2-4), Hypertension

explanation.intuition: AAA is fundamentally a disease of older men who smoke. The male predominance is striking - about 6 times more common in men than women. Smoking is so strongly associated that some call AAA a 'smoker's disease' - 90% of patients with AAA have a smoking history.
explanation.key_insight: The declining prevalence of AAA in developed countries correlates with declining smoking rates, confirming the causal relationship. However, as populations age, the absolute number of AAAs may still increase. Women tend to develop AAAs about 10 years later than men but have higher rupture risk at smaller diameters.
explanation.technical_details: Epidemiologic studies show AAA prevalence has decreased from ~5% to ~1.5% in screened populations over the past 20 years, paralleling smoking cessation trends. The heritability of AAA is estimated at 70%, with first-degree relatives having 2-4 fold increased risk. Associated conditions include peripheral arterial disease (40% have AAA), popliteal aneurysm (30-50% have AAA), and coronary artery disease. The incidence of ruptured AAA is approximately 5-10 per 100,000 person-years.
common_misconceptions: AAA is rare - it's actually one of the most common vascular pathologies
Only heavy smokers get AAA - any smoking history increases risk
Women don't get AAA - they do, but less commonly and later in life
AAA prevalence is increasing - it's actually declining in screened populations

definitions_glossary.prevalence: Proportion of population with disease at a given time
definitions_glossary.incidence: Rate of new cases occurring over time
definitions_glossary.relative_risk: Ratio of risk in exposed vs unexposed group
definitions_glossary.pack_years: Number of cigarette packs smoked per day × years of smoking
definitions_glossary.screening: Testing asymptomatic individuals to detect disease early

definition.@value: Population-level patterns of AAA occurrence, risk factors, and mortality

learning_objectives: Describe AAA prevalence by age and sex
Identify the major modifiable and non-modifiable risk factors
Explain the relationship between smoking and AAA risk
Understand the paradoxical protective effect of diabetes
Calculate relative risk for patients with multiple risk factors
common_errors: Not considering family history as a major risk factor
Applying male risk estimates to female patients
Forgetting to ask about smoking history in elderly patients
clinical_pearls: If you diagnose one AAA, screen first-degree relatives
90% of AAA patients have a smoking history
Diabetes is paradoxically protective - don't be surprised by non-diabetic AAA patients
Women rupture at smaller diameters - use sex-specific thresholds
